newsitem.title: CANADA: Ontario seen net importer of wheat on low output.
newsitem.headline: Ontario seen net importer of wheat on low output.

text.p: Canada's most populous province was expected to be a net importer of milling wheat as output was forecast to be a third to half lower than usual, an Ontario Wheat Producers Marketing Board official told Reuters.
"There will be no surplus wheat in Ontario. The milling industry here has already talked to the Canadian Wheat Board and other sources for wheat," OWPMB marketing manager Jim Whitelaw said.
Ontario usually seeds 765,000 acres of winter wheat but a severe fusarium headblight problem and a wet autumn cut seeding to between 350,000 and 400,000 acres, he said.
Normally, two-thirds of the crop is exported to the United States or overseas for human consumption.

"We expect a crop somewhere around 500,000 tonnes of three types of wheat," Whitelaw said. "With our production, if you take off seed, feed and on-farm use, the deliveries to the Board will be under 500,000 tonnes."
Annual domestic usage of Ontario's soft winter wheat is 425,000 tonnes, hard winter wheat is 200,000 tonnes, he said.
Ontario should need to import 50,000 to 60,000 tonnes of soft winter wheat and 100,000 to 150,000 tonnes of hard winter wheat, Whitelaw said.
Ontario's winter wheat harvest usually occurs between July 20 and August 15.
The OWPMB said last fall's seeding of winter wheats was Ontario's smallest plantings since the fall of 1991.
